hero.headline: Hello Traveller.
hero.subHeadline: Yo, it’s me Arsalan, aka Izake. I’ve been doing this web dev thing for a while now. Honestly, I just pick up whatever comes my way — then it’s all about figuring out how to make it work and keep it going. Here, you’ll find ideas, some finished projects, and some unfinished struggles.
hero.subHeadline1: Maybe it’s all part of the journey, after all.

aboutme.title: About Me
aboutme.desc_1: Alright buddy, I guess it’s time I spill the beans about myself. I'm a developer — though honestly, I’m not exactly sure what kind. Sometimes I work on web stuff, sometimes Android apps, and most of the time I’m just figuring things out as I go. I have a degree in Information Technology, but let’s be real — most of what I’ve actually learned came from messing around, following my curiosity, and just building things. And yeah, that also means a lot of time spent stuck on bugs. There have been nights where I’ve felt completely down just because I couldn’t get something to work the way I wanted it to.
aboutme.desc_2: I’m not the best with words, but this is me trying. Sharing a bit about myself. I could go on writing about how I do this and that, but honestly, that’s not really my style. I’ve always believed that actions speak louder than words — so this is probably the most I’ll ever write about myself. Truth is, I don’t fully know myself either — this “self” that everyone seems to think they’ve figured out. I'm just out here trying things, learning, building, failing, and trying again. That’s all there is to it.

experience.title: B.Sc in Information Technology
experience.summary: Studied theory. Learned more by doing.
experience.details: I did my B.Sc IT from Islamia College of Science and Commerce. It covered the usual stuff — data structures, programming, OS, networking, the works. And yeah, it sure gave me a foundation to work with, but the real learning happened elsewhere. YouTube tutorials - those 8 hour long videos, and just messing around. Still, it wasn't enough as when i met a senior dev. I was able to visualise the knowledge gap.

experience.title: Web Dev Intern @ NIT Srinagar under Astern Tech
experience.summary: Spend my time learning about clean coding paractices, tools and how React and javascript magic happens underneath
experience.details: During my internship at NIT Srinagar, I worked on mostly random things but they were all webdev inclined. I mostly did the things hard way to better understand how things work underneath for example instead of using react-router-dom i was instructed to create one myself and then use it. The experience grounded me, honestly humbled me down — I realized how different real-world development is from just gluing stuff together on your own.

projects.title: auto-boiler (npm package)
projects.summary: Wasted a few weeks to save a few minutes. Totally worth it.
projects.details: auto-boiler is a tiny Node.js CLI tool I published to npm. What does it do? Simple: it watches a folder in your project, and whenever you add a new file — boom — it auto-fills it with boilerplate code. JSX, TSX, JS, TS — whatever you like. You can even customize the templates or add your own file types. It’s like Emmet, but even lazier. I built it mostly because I was tired of writing the same stuff 10 times when setting up components. Got 138 downloads in 2 days after posting, which was cool - makes me feel better that i am not the only lazy one out there. Oh, and it's built using just Node’s built-in modules — no dependencies, works on all OSes. Mission Successfull.
